description.narrative:
Partnerskapet för kvinnors-, barns- och ungdomshälsa, PMNCH (ibland endast Partnerskapet) är världens största internationella partnerskap som syftar till att förbättra mödra-, barn och ungdomshälsan i världen. PMNCH har sökt bidrag till sin strategiska plan 2016-2020 genom förverkligandet av sin affärsplan för 2018-2020.
PMNCH skapades år 2005 med syfte att öka förutsättningarna för världens fattiga länder att uppnå milleniemålen 4 och 5 i en tid då resurser och politiskt engagemang för mödra-, barn och ungdomshälsa inte stod högst på den globala dagordningen. Idag omfattar partnerskapet över 1000 medlemmar som representerar länder i Syd, givare, multilateraler, akademiska institutioner, privata aktörer, civilsamhällsorganisationer, yrkesprofessionella organ samt ungdomsorganisationer. PMNCH har ett mindre sekretariat som huserar hos WHO i Geneve. Förutom att stärka partnerskapet kring huvudfrågorna är sekretariatets uppgift att samordna arbetet i partnerskapet med ett fokus på analys, ansvarsutkrävande, påverkansarbete och landengagemang. Kopplingen till FN:s globala strategi för kvinnors, barns och ungdomars hälsa 2016-2030 är institutionaliserad genom att PMNCH fått ett särskilt ansvar från FN:s generalsekreterare att följa upp genomförandet av den globala strategin och arbeta fram indikatorer för detta ändamål. En självständig panel, Independent Accountability Panel, har tillsatts som årligen rapporterar på efterlevnad av länders åtaganden och måluppföljning. Sida sitter i PMNCHS styrelse sedan 2013 och driver särskilt frågan om ett utökat fokus kring SRHR inklusive rätten till säkra aborter. Sida och Sveriges roll i partnerskapet är central med anledning av Sveriges starka engagemang och höga finansiering av SRHR globalt.
PMNCHs affärsplan för 2018-2020 har en budget på 30 miljoner USD. Den är finansierad av ca 15 givare från bilaterala organisationer, privata stiftelser och FN. Sidas bidrag är 12 MSEK under tre år (2019-2022), vilket utgör ca 4 % av den totala budgeten.

The Partnership for Women, Child and Adolescents' Health, PMNCH (in short referred to as the Partnership) is the world's largest international partnership aimed at improving maternal, child and adolescents' health in the world. PMNCH has applied for a contribution to its strategic plan 2016-2020 by realizing its business plan for 2018-2020.
PMNCH was created in 2005 with the aim of improving the conditions for the world's poor countries to achieve Millennium Goals 4 and 5 at a time when resources and political commitment to maternal, child and adolescents health were not high on the global agenda. Today, the partnership includes over 1,000-member organisations representing countries in the South, donors, multilateral, academic institutions, private actors, civil society organizations, professional bodies, and youth organizations. PMNCH has a small secretariat that is housed at the WHO in Geneva. In addition to strengthening the partnership on the main issues, the secretariat's task is to coordinate and align the work in the partnership with a focus on analysis, accountability, advocacy and country engagement. The link to the UN's global strategy for women's, children's and adolescents' health (2016-2030) is institutionalized by PMNCH being given a special responsibility by the UN Secretary-General to follow up the implementation of the global strategy and to develop indicators for this purpose. An independent panel, the Independent Accountability Panel, has been appointed to report annually on compliance of countries' commitments. Sida is a member of the PMNCHs board since 2013 and in particular advocaet for and monitor the issue of an expanded focus on SRHR including the right to safe abortions. Sida and Sweden's role in the partnership is central to Sweden's strong commitment and high funding of SRHR globally.
PMNCH's business plan for 2018-2020 has a budget of $ 30 million. It is funded by 15 donors from bilateral organizations, private foundations and the UN. Sida's contribution is SEK 12 million for three years (2019-2022), which represents about 4% of the total budget.

The Partnerships vision is a world in which every woman, child and adolescent in every setting realises their rights to physical and mental health and well-being has social and economic opportunities and is able to participate fully in shaping prosperous and sustainable societies and its mission is to increase the engagement, alignment and accountability of partners by creating a multistakeholder platform to support successful implementation of the Global Strategy with a life course approach to health and sustainable development, the goal being to enable all people to live healthy and long lives and contribute to sustainable development. A Theory of Change and Results Framework is presented in the 2018-2020 Business Plan, identifying priority objectives and results that the Partnership will deliver during the period. It is organized in six thematic workstreams and aligned with the six focus areas of the EWEC Partners Framework 2020. The priority objectives 2020 are as follows:1) Early Childhood Development (ECD) - Support of integration of ECD programming in 5-10 existing national WCAH policies, services and programmes.2) Adolescents - Supporting partners to align around the development of 5-10 national plans for adolescents and support national youth-led coalitions to strengthen skills and knowledge of adolescents to exercise their rights to make informed choices. 3) Quality, equity and dignity (QED) - Support partners to integrate QED in 5-10 national Universal health coverage (UHC).4) Sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) - Ensure the adoption and promotion of a comprehensive, integrated definition of SRHR and the inclusion of the essential sexual and reproductive health interventions in UHC in 5-10 countries. 5) Empowerment - Support women, children and adolescents as agents of change and strengthen community engagement in promoting laws, policies and social norms that advance WCAH and rights.6) Humanitarian and fragile settings (HFS) - Support alignment, adoption and promotion of WCAH essential services in programmes and interventions in 5-10 HFS. The results are to be delivered, as presented in the 2018-2020 Business Plan, through the four "As":Analysis - It shall increase access to and use of knowledge to enhance policy, service delivery and financing mechanisms for WCAH. Alignment - Align partners to increase WCAH commitments and financing and integrate into 5-10 national UHC plans - including GFF Investment Cases, through strengthening multistakeholder, multisectoral platforms at country level. Advocacy - Advocate for mobilizing and aligning resources and greater engagement with and focus on WCAH at global, regional and country levels and biold digital advocacy channels. Accountability - Ensure effective tracking of the Global Strategy's goal and of national commitments to WCAH, including through supporting partner engagement and accountability at the national level and through hosting the IAP. The above will contribute to the EWEC Partners' Framework 2020, considered as and referred to as "Shared Deliverables". The outcomes 2020 will impact the Global Strategy (2016 - 2030) and thus PMNCHs work will contribute directly to achievements and the related SDG Targets. To do so, approaches and tools such as partnership-centric approach, political engagement activities, strategic alignment and a digital strategy, will be used.

participating-org.narrative: World Health Organisation - core voluntary contributions account

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.
